caption_original: Look how far this Bluefin tuna travelled last winter! Our fishery officers and biologists worked together to recover a tag off Shippagan, New Brunswick, that had been attached to a Bluefin tuna for over a year. It showed the tuna was originally tagged on October 17, 2016 off of Port Mouton, Nova Scotia. The tuna stayed in Canadian waters until December and then travelled 3,000 km to the southwest of the Azores before making its way back to Nova Scotia in April. Effective immediately, vessels travelling in the western Gulf of St. Lawrence are mandated to reduce their speed to a maximum of 10 knots. The Government of Canada implemented the temporary mandatory slow-down for vessels longer than 20 metres in an effort to minimize risks to right whales in the area.

 
Following the recent whale deaths in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, we are making every effort possible to prevent further incidents and continue to work on the recovery of the species. We are awaiting results from the necropsies, and we have closed snow crab fishing to prevent entanglements.  Other fixed gear fisheries such as rock and toad crab fisheries have either been restricted to fish in shallow water or have had a delayed opening. For more information on our actions to date: http://ow.ly/n5qc30el2Kw

caption_original: Northern Snakehead is an invasive species that has not yet been found in any of Canada’s aquatic ecosystems, but we want to be on the lookout! Most snakehead species are native to warmer regions, but the Northern Snakehead occurs naturally in colder waters. Northern Snakehead can eat practically any small animal or fish they encounter. They can travel across land and live out of water for at least three days and reproduce quickly. If they find a way into natural freshwater ecosystems, they have the potential to cause serious damage to recreational and commercial fisheries. Report sightings: http://ow.ly/J8pb30gvleY

For the past two years, our team of Quebec biologists has been collecting data on artificial reefs developed for American lobster in the Magdalen Islands and the Gaspé Peninsula. These 10m by 20m reefs are composed mainly of rocks of different sizes. They serve to offset the serious harm caused by marine environment projects by providing shelter and food for lobsters of all sizes. They become true nurseries for these crustaceans and are also, according to what the dives on the sites have shown, colonized by a wide variety of organisms.

caption_original: Help protect our oceans! We work hard to keep Canada’s waters and coasts safe and clean through programs and initiatives like the Oceans Protection Plan and Coastal Restoration Fund. But we can’t do it alone. To encourage the public to get involved, we visit communities with educational materials and take part in school visits and beach clean-ups. Unfortunately, the waters around many Canadian harbours aren’t as clean as they could be. Recently, our researchers from Newfoundland and Labrador, Corey Morris & Dan Porter, presented results from a survey of 18 harbours over 10 years. During scientific dives, they unexpectedly found, and videotaped, lots of garbage – everything from carpet, rubber gloves, rubber boots to appliances like BBQs, stove, even a washer with laundry still inside. Everyone has a role in protecting the ocean and the creatures that live there. Reduce the garbage going into the ocean by recycling, reusing and refusing plastic where you can.

Round Goby are also found in some inland waters in southern Ontario such as Lake Simcoe, the Trent River, Rice Lake, and parts of the Otonabee River. If you’re a boater or fisher, it’s important to learn to identify Asian carp, an aquatic invasive species. 
The term, “Asian carp” actually refers to four species of carps. Black Carp have a blunt, scaleless head with a small toothless mouth, and no barbels. They have a pointed snout and a slightly downturned mouth. The body is long and narrow and the dorsal fin is shorter than that of Common Carp. Scales are very large with dark edges, giving a cross-hatched appearance. If you think you’ve found a Black Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/QoOk30fUGLu

caption_original: The ecosystem research team in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, came across a bird colony! A glaucous gull colony of approximately 25 couples was found on a cliff at the far south of the strait. These birds can nest in different habitats, like cliffs and wetlands. As a result, they have a broad diet. Remains of fish of different sizes and even lemming bones were found, providing a picture of their diet. The cliff offers gull eggs and young birds protection against predators and excellent access to marine resources.

caption_original: Arctic sculpins live in deep and shallow waters where they eat small crustaceans, other small fish and fish larvae. They can tolerate water as cold as -2°C. In order to survive these extreme conditions, they developed a special antifreeze protein to prevent their blood from freezing solid. Sculpins may be a predicator of changes at the bottom of the food web. Learn to identify invasive species! 
Silver Carp is one of four species of invasive Asian carp and is best known for its startled response. You’ve probably seen videos of them leaping as high as three metres above the water’s surface when disturbed by boat motors or other noise. 
Silver Carp have a large, scaleless head, and a toothless mouth without barbels. Closely related to Bighead Carp, Silver Carp tends to be narrower in shape. They are greyish-black on top and have small, curved scales. They can live up to 20 years!

The Tubenose Goby is a small, bottom-dwelling invasive fish that lives among the aquatic vegetation found in nearshore waters of lakes and rivers. Since its discovery in North America in the late 1980s, Tubenose Goby have been found in a few locations in the Great Lakes. To prevent the spread of this invasive species, never buy or use Tubenose Goby as bait, and never transfer live bait between waterbodies. It is against the law. Scientists are concerned about the possible long-term effects, because it can beat resident fish for habitat and food. This is a real concern for bottom-dwelling fishes, like Rainbow Darter and Northern Madtom.
